title: Moniker’s Senior Designer Search Signals Big Bets on Visual Identity from San Francisco Studio

paragraphs.content: San Francisco–based identity studio Moniker has opened applications for a **Senior Designer** role that will be “100% focused on visual identity work,” designing brand systems that scale across complex organizations, digital products, and real‑world environments.The vacancy, highlighted by design publication BP&O on December 23, 2025, positions the hire at the center of Moniker’s brand‑systems practice for high‑profile clients in technology, health, energy, and the arts.Moniker describes the job as hands‑on and highly collaborative, suited to someone equally comfortable defining a core visual idea and building the detailed components that make a system work “in the wild.”Candidates are invited to apply whether they are full‑time, freelance, or contract, provided they bring a strong identity portfolio and can overlap with West Coast working hours.

The studio’s own News page calls for an “exceptional Senior Designer” with a portfolio centered on innovative visual identities and an interest in design, culture, and business, underscoring how integral the role is to Moniker’s positioning as an identity specialist.Moniker combines design, language, and strategy to give companies “greater agency” over who they are and how they operate, and lists clients such as CoreWeave, Coinbase, Intuit, Meta, One Medical, and Natura Resources—organizations that rely heavily on scalable brand systems.The opening lands amid a competitive Bay Area market for senior design talent, where hundreds of senior‑level roles span product, UX, and visual design, making a pure identity position relatively distinct.By emphasizing motion, 3D, and coded graphics as plus skills, Moniker signals its interest in cross‑disciplinary designers who can push identity beyond static applications.

sections.title: A Hands‑On Identity Role at the Heart of Moniker’s Client Work

paragraphs.content: BP&O’s listing frames the Senior Designer role as an opportunity to work on brand systems for “industry leaders at the forefront of technology,” naming clients like CoreWeave, Coinbase, Intuit, and Meta alongside sports, energy, health, and arts organizations.Moniker’s studio site echoes this breadth, presenting itself as an identity practice that blends visual design with language and strategy to clarify how companies present their value to the world.The job description states the designer will focus entirely on visual identity, from concepting to detailed system implementation across interfaces, products, and environments, rather than splitting time with product or marketing design.This scope aligns with Moniker’s recent case‑study work, including Quilt’s home‑energy identity and visual systems for brands recognized in awards circuits.

On its News page, Moniker asks for applicants who are “chill, extremely passionate about design, culture, and business,” while also flagging skills in 3D, motion, and processing as strong advantages, suggesting an appetite for experimental, multi‑modal brand expression. The same page places the Senior Designer listing alongside a Project Manager role and multiple new‑work announcements, indicating a wider growth phase tied to identity‑driven engagements across tech and culture. Past coverage of the studio’s collaborations—such as tactile, abstract paper posters for Designer Fund and a “tasty” brand identity for artisan chocolate maker Mita—illustrates a track record of translating conceptual ideas into highly crafted visual systems. Taken together, these signals suggest the new Senior Designer will be expected to navigate both strategic thinking and meticulous execution for clients ranging from startups to global corporations.

sections.title: West Coast Hours, Remote Flexibility, and a Competitive Senior Design Market

paragraphs.content: While Moniker is based in San Francisco, both the studio’s listing and BP&O’s coverage stress that applicants do not need to live in the city, so long as they maintain “meaningful overlap” with West Coast working hours. This hybrid‑friendly stance reflects a broader shift in senior design roles, where remote collaboration is increasingly normalized, even as studios maintain physical hubs in major markets like the Bay Area. Job aggregators show hundreds of senior design openings across San Francisco and the wider Bay Area, spanning product, UX, and visual roles, underscoring how Moniker’s identity‑only focus differentiates it within a crowded field. Other listings—such as senior visual design contracts and senior design manager positions at large tech companies—highlight alternative paths that tilt more toward product ecosystems or design operations than pure brand systems.

In this context, Moniker’s emphasis on identity craft, motion and 3D fluency, and cross‑industry brand work positions the Senior Designer role as a niche opportunity for specialists who want to stay close to core brand ideas rather than migrate fully into product or UX. The studio’s continuing presence in design press, awards recognition for projects like Intuit and Air Company, and inclusion on lists of top creative workplaces all serve as indirect signals of its appeal to senior‑level talent. For candidates, the absence of published salary details and team‑structure specifics means conversations during the application process will be crucial for understanding scope, leadership expectations, and growth pathways. As Moniker continues to expand its roster—from energy and climate clients to arts and health organizations—the Senior Designer hire is poised to help shape how these brands appear and behave across an increasingly complex landscape of touchpoints.

sidebarSections: A Hands‑On Identity Role at the Heart of Moniker’s Client Work
West Coast Hours, Remote Flexibility, and a Competitive Senior Design Market
